 Nonsense. The very fact that there exists an independent regulatory agency (the FCC), whose purpose is to regulate broadcasting distinguishes broadcast media from other media. The government is allowed certain control over the airwaves because the spectrum is limited, and oversight is needed so that the people, who the airwaves actually belong to, can be adequately served. There are no such limits to publishing because paper is cheap and abundant. Such a hypothetical is especially absurd now that just about everyone and their mother has a blog. Furthermore, I know of no liberal or liberal group that does anything close to advocating such a thing. In the 38 years that Fairness Doctrine was actually FCC policy, can you name any examples where the expression of an opinion was actually prevented? I've heard a lot of talk that it's "censorship" but I have yet to hear any examples.
 
 
Personally, I think liberals are reluctant to debate the conservative talk show hosts. I have heard many a story about how certain liberals have been invited to come on various shows to debate issues, only to refuse for some dubious reason...like scheduling conflicts. Few accept the invitations...likely because they realize that their arguments do not hold water very long...or that they will actually have to answer some tough questions...and will be requested to adhere to logic and truth in their arguments.
 
 It is plainly a case of ineptness fighting back with claims of unfairness in the arena.

 
 And I've heard many a story about how conservative hosts carefully screen callers to find those that agree with them, or those that would make the host look better by arguing poorly against them. Are liberals afraid to go on such shows? Or, do they recognize that the very nature of the program makes it incredibly difficult for rational discourse to occur? One account seems to support the latter. This isn't necessarily representative of the whole, but I think it is a fair assessment.
 
 Let me be clear. As I've said before, I'm not advocating for reinstating the Fairness Doctrine (at least not by Congressional mandate), I just have seen far too much misrepresentation of what it was, historically. It seems like there is a lot of false outrage because a few Democrats have expressed interest, even though support of such is not necessarily widespread across the party. For example, the President-Elect does not support it. So, I think that claims of "liberals trying to suppress conservatives" are overblown, not only because the Fairness Doctrine has been misrepresented, but it is not as widely supported as some claim.
 
 I do, however, think that we would be well served to have stricter ownership caps and better enforcement of the public interest standard. As stated in The Public and Broadcasting:
 
In exchange for obtaining a valuable license to operate a broadcast station using the public airwaves, each radio and television licensee is required by law to operate its station in the "public interest, convenience and necessity." This means that it must air programming that is responsive to the needs and problems of its local community of license.

 Frankly, with all of the technology at our disposal, I think the Fairness Doctrine is largely obsolete and unnecessary. It might be nice if licensees would at least operate in the spirit of allowing opposing views on controversial issues, but I think that terrestrial radio is a dying breed anyway. I think fivethirtyeight.com had an interesting analysis on the subject. What it stems from should maybe be saved for another thread, but I agree with his closing sentiment, that "conservatives now need to find a way to communicate with people who are actually paying attention."
